articles.title: Scientists are closing in on the Universe’s biggest mystery
articles.summary: Nearly everything in the universe is made of mysterious dark matter and dark energy, yet we can’t see either of them directly. Scientists are developing detectors so sensitive they can spot particle interactions that might occur once in years or even decades. These experiments aim to uncover what shapes galaxies and fuels cosmic expansion. Cracking this mystery could transform our understanding of the laws of nature.
articles.content:
Scientists have learned a great deal about the universe, yet that knowledge represents only a small fraction of the full picture. Roughly 95% of the cosmos is made up of dark matter and dark energy, leaving just 5% as the familiar matter we can see around us. Dr. Rupak Mahapatra, an experimental particle physicist at Texas A&M University, is working to uncover this hidden majority by designing advanced semiconductor detectors equipped with cryogenic quantum sensors. These technologies support experiments around the world and are helping researchers push deeper into one of science's greatest mysteries.

Mahapatra compares humanity's limited understanding of the universe -- or lack thereof -- to a well-known parable. "It's like trying to describe an elephant by only touching its tail. We sense something massive and complex, but we're only grasping a tiny part of it."

Mahapatra and his co-authors recently had their work featured in the respected journal Applied Physics Letters.

What Are Dark Matter and Dark Energy?

Dark matter and dark energy are named for what scientists do not yet know about them. Dark matter makes up most of the mass found in galaxies and galaxy clusters, playing a major role in shaping their structure across vast cosmic distances. Dark energy refers to the force behind the universe's accelerating expansion. Put simply, dark matter acts like cosmic glue, while dark energy drives space itself to expand faster and faster.

Although both are abundant, neither dark matter nor dark energy gives off, absorbs, or reflects light, which makes direct observation extremely difficult. Scientists instead study their influence through gravity, which affects how galaxies move and how large-scale structures form. Dark energy is the dominant component, accounting for about 68% of the universe's total energy, while dark matter contributes roughly 27%.

Detecting Whispers in a Hurricane

At Texas A&M, Mahapatra's research group is developing detectors with extraordinary sensitivity. These instruments are designed to detect particles that interact with ordinary matter only on rare occasions, interactions that could provide critical clues about the nature of dark matter.

"The challenge is that dark matter interacts so weakly that we need detectors capable of seeing events that might happen once in a year, or even once in a decade," Mahapatra said.

His team played a role in a leading global dark matter search using a detector known as TESSERACT. "It's about innovation," he said. "We're finding ways to amplify signals that were previously buried in noise."

Texas A&M is among a small group of institutions participating in the TESSERACT experiments.

Pushing the Limits of Detection

Mahapatra's current efforts build on decades of experience in advancing particle detection methods. For the past 25 years, he has contributed to the SuperCDMS experiment, which has conducted some of the most sensitive dark matter searches in the world. In a landmark 2014 paper published in Physical Review Letters, Mahapatra and his collaborators introduced voltage-assisted calorimetric ionization detection in the SuperCDMS experiment -- a breakthrough that made it possible to study low-mass WIMPs, a leading dark matter candidate. This advance significantly improved scientists' ability to detect particles that had previously been beyond reach.

In 2022, Mahapatra co-authored another study examining multiple approaches to finding a WIMP, including direct detection, indirect detection and collider searches. The work highlights the importance of combining different strategies to tackle the dark matter problem.

"No single experiment will give us all the answers," Mahapatra notes. "We need synergy between different methods to piece together the full picture."

Understanding dark matter goes far beyond academic curiosity. It could reveal fundamental principles that govern the universe itself. "If we can detect dark matter, we'll open a new chapter in physics," Mahapatra said. "The search needs extremely sensitive sensing technologies and it could lead to technologies we can't even imagine today."

What Are WIMPs?

WIMPs (Weakly Interacting Massive Particles) are considered one of the most promising possibilities for dark matter. These hypothetical particles would interact through gravity and the weak nuclear force, which explains why they are so difficult to detect.

articles.personality_title: Scientists develop ultra-sensitive detectors to uncover dark matter and dark energy
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists know that about 95% of the universe is made up of dark matter and dark energy, mysterious substances that cannot be seen directly. Dark matter helps shape galaxies, while dark energy makes the universe expand faster. Despite their importance, these components remain largely unknown because they do not emit or reflect light.

**What happened** – Dr. Rupak Mahapatra and his team at Texas A&M University are creating advanced detectors with cryogenic quantum sensors that can spot rare particle interactions linked to dark matter. These detectors are so sensitive they might detect events happening only once in years or decades. Their work supports global experiments like TESSERACT and builds on decades of progress, including breakthroughs in detecting weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs), a leading candidate for dark matter.

**Impact** – These ultra-sensitive detectors allow scientists to explore parts of the universe that were previously hidden. By capturing subtle signals from dark matter, researchers can better understand how galaxies form and why the universe is expanding. This work could change how we understand the laws of physics and lead to new technologies.

**What's next step** – Scientists will continue improving these detectors and combine different methods, such as direct searches and collider experiments, to find clearer evidence of dark matter. Ongoing experiments like TESSERACT will use these tools to gather more data, moving closer to solving this cosmic mystery.

**One-sentence takeaway** – New highly sensitive detectors are helping scientists detect rare signals from dark matter and dark energy, bringing us closer to understanding most of the universe’s hidden makeup.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des détecteurs ultra-sensibles développés pour révéler la matière et l’énergie sombres
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques savent qu’environ 95 % de l’univers est constitué de matière sombre et d’énergie sombre, des substances mystérieuses invisibles directement. La matière sombre façonne les galaxies, tandis que l’énergie sombre accélère l’expansion de l’univers. Malgré leur importance, ces composants restent largement inconnus car ils n’émettent ni ne reflètent la lumière.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le Dr Rupak Mahapatra et son équipe de l’Université Texas A&M créent des détecteurs avancés avec des capteurs quantiques cryogéniques capables de repérer de rares interactions de particules liées à la matière sombre. Ces détecteurs sont tellement sensibles qu’ils peuvent détecter des événements qui se produisent une fois par an, voire une fois par décennie. Leur travail soutient des expériences mondiales comme TESSERACT et s’appuie sur des décennies de progrès, y compris des avancées dans la détection des particules massives faiblement interagissantes (WIMPs), un candidat principal pour la matière sombre.

**Impact** – Ces détecteurs ultra-sensibles permettent aux scientifiques d’explorer des parties de l’univers auparavant cachées. En captant des signaux subtils de la matière sombre, les chercheurs peuvent mieux comprendre la formation des galaxies et l’accélération de l’univers. Ce travail pourrait changer notre compréhension des lois de la physique et ouvrir la voie à de nouvelles technologies.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont continuer à améliorer ces détecteurs et combiner différentes méthodes, comme les recherches directes et les expériences en collisionneur, pour trouver des preuves plus claires de la matière sombre. Les expériences en cours comme TESSERACT utiliseront ces outils pour recueillir plus de données, se rapprochant ainsi de la résolution de ce mystère cosmique.

**Résumé en une phrase** – De nouveaux détecteurs très sensibles aident les scientifiques à détecter des signaux rares provenant de la matière et de l’énergie sombres, nous rapprochant de la compréhension de la majeure partie de la composition cachée de l’univers.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos desarrollan detectores ultrasensibles para descubrir la materia y energía oscuras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos saben que aproximadamente el 95 % del universo está formado por materia oscura y energía oscura, sustancias misteriosas que no se pueden ver directamente. La materia oscura ayuda a formar galaxias, mientras que la energía oscura hace que el universo se expanda más rápido. A pesar de su importancia, estos componentes siguen siendo poco conocidos porque no emiten ni reflejan luz.

**Qué pasó** – El Dr. Rupak Mahapatra y su equipo en la Universidad Texas A&M están creando detectores avanzados con sensores cuánticos criogénicos que pueden detectar raras interacciones de partículas relacionadas con la materia oscura. Estos detectores son tan sensibles que podrían captar eventos que ocurren una vez cada años o incluso décadas. Su trabajo apoya experimentos globales como TESSERACT y se basa en décadas de avances, incluyendo descubrimientos en la detección de partículas masivas débilmente interactuantes (WIMPs), un candidato principal para la materia oscura.

**Impacto** – Estos detectores ultrasensibles permiten a los científicos explorar partes del universo que antes estaban ocultas. Al captar señales sutiles de la materia oscura, los investigadores pueden entender mejor cómo se forman las galaxias y por qué el universo se está expandiendo. Este trabajo podría cambiar nuestra comprensión de las leyes de la física y conducir a nuevas tecnologías.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos continuarán mejorando estos detectores y combinando diferentes métodos, como búsquedas directas y experimentos en colisionadores, para encontrar evidencia más clara de la materia oscura. Experimentos en curso como TESSERACT usarán estas herramientas para recolectar más datos, acercándonos a resolver este misterio cósmico.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Nuevos detectores altamente sensibles están ayudando a los científicos a detectar señales raras de materia y energía oscuras, acercándonos a entender la mayor parte de la composición oculta del universo.
